Award.AwardTitle: IRES: Nanomaterials undergraduate Research in Germany (NanoRING)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1
The NSF-IRES program Nanomaterials undergraduate Research in Germany (NanoRING) will provide 10-week nanoresearch opportunities at the Technical University of Munich (TUM), Germany for five US undergraduates from the combined student pool of Northwestern University (NU) and the Univerity of Texas in San Antonio (UTSA), a minority serving institution and partner of NU. The specific research focus is on nanomaterials covering the subtopics of nanoelectronics, nanophotonics, and nano-biomaterials. This thematic base leverages TUM?s International Graduate School of Science and Engineering (IGSSE).
The research opportunity will be for undergraduates only, in order to motivate and inspire young US researchers to invest in a future research career. Particularly at UTSA, specific efforts will be made to reach out to underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines so that the cohort?s constituency will meet or exceed NSF?s goals for representation. Individual German collaborators from within IGSSE have provided letters of collaboration to host visiting student researchers.

Part 2
Unique materials science expertise outside of the U.S. is particularly strong in Germany. Electron transport experiments, crystal growth, heterostructure design, graphene characterization, quantum dot spectroscopy, biosensor nanotechnology, and photonic emitters / detectors all represent topics of research expertise and mentorship that will benefit U.S. students. By training U.S. graduate and undergraduate students at these facilities, students can learn unique skills to advance their education and training. Furthermore, since they are researching
abroad, students will develop an identity within the international scientific community, building up a professional network and getting a first-hand perspective of larger scope of a research career. The administrative structure of NanoRING will leverage existing infrastructures at German universities through TUM?s graduate school for international students IGSSE where the administrators have exhaustive experience hosting international student research visitors.

One of the greatest intended payoffs of a student research-abroad experience is career retention. By developing engineering and science skills in a supportive and engaging multicultural environment, undergraduates will recognize their place within an international peer community and will be motivated to continue their positive experience in a career in STEM research. This is particularly important for underrepresented groups within STEM disciplines. To enhance participation of underrepresented groups, outreach to target student groups will meet or exceed NSF goals for representation by coordinating with minority student groups at both NU and UTSA. After the visit abroad, students will make a scientific presentation to their home institution, and to their underrepresented group, where applicable. The will also have the opportunity to apply for an additional Publication Award to publish or present their scientific work at a conference, promoting broad dissemination of results. A post-program assessment will assess program structure & content, track career choices, and a questionnaire will discern the impact that these research-abroad experience had on the students, their peers, and the broader scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF International Research Experience for Students called "NanoRING - Nanotechnology Research in Germany" concluded after 3 years having provided the opportunity for 14 U.S. undergraduates to conduct 10 weeks of research at the Technical University of Munich in Germany.  This effort was a collaboration between Northwestern University (NU) and the University of Texas, San Antonio (UTSA), and students from both institutions participated each year. 

The following are the titles of the 14 research projects conducted under this support at the Technical University of Munich:

2016:

1) "ATP-Consuming Molecular Machines"
Jessica Beard (NU), Research Group of Prof. Friedrich Simmel, Mentored by Marisa G?tzfried and Dr. Tobias Pirzer

2) "Novel Zinc Complex: Synthesis, Characterization, and Reactivity towards CO2 Activation"
Zachary Hern (UTSA), Research Group Prof. Corinna Hess, Mentored by Ruth Haas

3) "Thermoelectric power factor measurement of AlGaAs at different
aluminum compositions and carrier concentrations"
Stephan Kim (NU), Research Group Dr. Gregor Koblmueller, Mentored by Dr. Damon Carrad

4) "Integrated photonic circuits based on Transitional Metal Dichalcogenides and Superconducting nanowire Single Photon Detectors"
Lawrence A Rhoads (UTSA), Research Group Prof. Jon Finley, Mentored by Fabian Flassig

5) "Electrical Characterization of Single and Single-Junction Silver Nanowires"
Jordan Scherer (NU), Research Group Prof. Paolo Lugli, Mentored by Marco Bobinger

2017:

6) "Impact of Heparin on Kinetic Parameters for RNA-guided Endonuclease Cas9"
Anam Furrukh (NU), Group of Dr. Ulrich Rant at Dynamic Biosensors GmbH, Mentored by Felix Kroener

7) "Voltage Response of Multi-Photon Resolving Superconducting Nanowire Single Photon Detectors"
Gregory Mulderink (NU), Group of Prof. Jonathan Finley, Mentored by Fabian Flassig

8) "Bacteria@AgNPs in-situ synthesis: Antibacterial Effectiveness on E. coli using SERS"
Heidi Ramsower (UTSA), Group of Dr. Christoph Haisch, Mentored by David Bauer

9) "Enhancement of Acoustically driven Ferromagnetic Resonance"
Christopher Sims (NU), Group of Prof. Hans Huebl, Mentored by Clemens M?hlenhoff and Matthias Weiler

2018:

10) "Validating MenG as a target for a novel antibiotic against MRSA using mass spectrometry"
Katherine Duncker (NU), Group of Prof. Stephan Sieber, Mentored by Robert Macsics

11) "Study of PON1 to Produce Lactone from PHA to Produce Bioplastics
with Desired Mechanical Properties"
Soram Kim (NU), Group of Prof. Dr. Thomas Br?ck, Mentored by Samer Younes

12) "The Analysis of Integrated Capacitive Stretch Sensors in Compression Pants for Knee Angle Measurements"
Yakira I. Mirabito (NU), Group of Prof. Veit Senner, Mentored by Aljoscha Hermann

13) "Investigation of Different Sized Magnetic Nanoparticles Attached to
Cells in Magnetic Flow Cytometry"
Natalia Rafiq (UTSA), Group of Prof. Oliver Hayden, Mentored by Mathias Reisbeck

14) "ZnO Films for Applications in Hybrid Solar Cells"
Shaleahk Wilson (NU), Group of Prof. Peter M?ller-Buschbaum, Mentored by Kun Wang

Demographics: 8/14 female; 1/14 Hispanic; 2/14 Black.

The 2017 year was documented with video interviews by AAAS Fellow Prof. Jarita Holbrook under NSF support.  Hypertext link for videos below:

https://sites.google.com/uwc.ac.za/video-astroanthro-org/home/nsf-ires-films

Students were guided in their research with weekly research assignments towards completion of their 10-week research goals.  In their final project assessments, students acknowledged that this experience helped them to identify their research interests in future STEM research careers.  In this light, this IRES award has achieved its primary deliverable, which is to train young US researchers to be adept in navigating international scientific communities, creating new international professional connections, and identifying opportunites for international leadership in STEM professions.


Last Modified: 08/17/2019
Modified by: Matthew A Grayson
